linkedin_essay.text:
The energy transition â€” the shift from fossil fuels to renewable energy, electric vehicles, and battery storage â€” is the largest industrial transformation since electrification. It is also, by a considerable margin, the most mineral-intensive. A conventional car requires roughly 20 kilogrammes of copper. An electric vehicle requires 80 kilogrammes â€” four times as much â€” plus lithium, cobalt, nickel, manganese, and graphite for the battery, and rare earth elements for the permanent magnets in the motor (IEA, 2021). An offshore wind turbine requires approximately 8 tonnes of copper, 2 tonnes of rare earths, and hundreds of tonnes of steel (World Bank, 2020). Solar panels require silicon, silver, and increasingly tellurium and indium for thin-film technologies.

The International Energy Agency estimates that achieving the Paris Agreement's climate targets would require a quadrupling of mineral inputs by 2040 compared to 2020 levels (IEA, 2021). Lithium demand alone would need to increase by over forty times. Cobalt and nickel by roughly twenty times. Copper demand would need to double by 2035 â€” and the world has not opened a major new copper mine in over a decade.

Here is where these minerals come from, and why that matters.
